(7401451781); Lersvanichkool, Ackadech (57130926200); Bui, Van Hanh (59224167400); Tanaka, Manabu (25641191700)
Title: Elucidation of droplet detachment mechanism in metal-cored arc welding
Affiliations: Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; CSIRO Manufacturing, Australia; Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Tashiro, Shinichi, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Trinh, Quang Ngoc, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Dang Khoi, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Suga, Tetsuo, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Kakizaki, Tomonori, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Yamazaki, Kei, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Murphy, Anthony B., CSIRO Manufacturing, Australia; Lersvanichkool, Ackadech, Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand; Bui, Van Hanh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tanaka, Manabu, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: It has been demonstrated experimentally that a globular transfer mode tends to occur in argon gas metal arc welding using a metal-cored wire (called metal-red arc welding (MCAW)) even under conditions where a spray transfer mode occurs when a solid wire is used. This study aimed to elucidate the droplet detachment mechanism in MCAW using numerical simulations. It was observed that in the initial stage of droplet growth, the argon arc attachment (which carried a large portion of the current) was located on the metal sheath surrounding the unmelted flux. Moreover, an eddy containing an upward flow at the wire axis was formed inside the droplet. When this eddy was formed, the droplet volume increased owing to wire melting. However, neck formation did not occur. This is considered to be because only a small portion of the current is conducted through the droplet, and the Lorentz force acting on the droplet is significantly weak. Thereafter, when the droplet grew to a certain extent and the arc attachment moved below the unmelted flux position, the Lorentz force acted strongly and almost uniformly on the droplet. Accordingly, this eddy disappeared, and the flow abruptly transitioned to a downward unidirectional high-speed flow. Consequently, the droplet began to extend downward to form a neck, which caused it to detach. For these reasons, the time required for droplet detachment increased, and the metal transfer frequency decreased compared with the case of the solid wire. This explains the observation that globular transfer persists in metal-cored wires at currents higher than those for which the transition to spray transfer has occurred for solid wires. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Argon; Gas Metal Arc Welding; Gas Welding; Lorentz Force; Wire; 'current; Arc Attachment; Arc-welding; Argon Gas; Droplet Detachment; Globular Transfer; Metal Cored Wires; Solid Wires; Spray Transfer; Transfer Modes; Drops

Title: Optimization of metal transfer in rutile flux-cored arc welding through controlled CO2 concentration in argon–CO2 shielding gas
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; CSIRO Manufacturing, Clayton, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Trinh, Ngoc Quang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Khoidang, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Tashiro, Shinichi, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Suga, Tetsuo, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Sasakura, Shuji, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Fukuda, Kazuhiro, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Murphy, Anthony B., CSIRO Manufacturing, Clayton, Australia; van Bui, Hanh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tanaka, Manabu, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: In this study, we analyzed the impact of carbon dioxide concentration in argon–carbon dioxide shielding gas on droplet transfer characteristics in rutile flux-cored arc welding, employing titanium oxide as a primary wire flux component. The welding process was carried out at a welding current of 190, 220, 250, 280, and 310 A under an argon–CO<inf>2</inf> shielding gas mixture with six levels of CO<inf>2</inf> concentration of 0, 5 %, 10 %, 15 %, 20 %, and 25 % for a parametric study. Unlike the conventional solid wire welding trend, where the droplet transfer frequency decreases with the increase in carbon dioxide concentration, an increase in metal transfer frequency was observed with the increase in CO<inf>2</inf> concentration from approximately 5 % to 20 %. The concentration reaching the maximum frequency was 20 % at 190 A, which decreased as the welding current increased, reaching 5 % at 310 A. Droplet initiation at the lower sheath end is succeeded by a gradual downward movement along the flux column's side after a few milliseconds. Upon reaching the lower end, the droplet forms a neck and undergoes separation. Thus, the length of the flux column directly impacts the duration of one droplet transfer cycle. The length was decreased by arc constriction when increasing CO<inf>2</inf> concentration appropriately to concentrate beneath the flux column or by increasing the welding current to raise the arc temperature, which contributed to melting and shortening the flux column. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Research assessing personality traits and religiosity across cultures has typically neglected variation across religious affiliations and has been limited to a small number of personality traits. This study examines the relationship between the Big Five personality traits and their facets, two theoretically distinct measures of religiosity, and twelve other personality traits across seven religious affiliations and 61 countries/regions. The proportion of participants following a religion varied substantially across countries (e.g., Indonesia = 99%; Estonia = 7%). Both measures of religiosity were related to agreeableness, conscientiousness, happiness, and fairness; however; relations with religiosity as a social axiom were stronger and less variable across religious affiliations. Additionally, personality-religiosity links were more robust in low-development, high-conflict, and collectivist nations. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Country Variation; Personality Traits; Religiosity; Religious Affiliations

Authors with affiliations: Watanabe, Motoko, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; Takao, Chihiro, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; Maeda, Chizuko, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; Nayanar, Gayatri Krishnakumar, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; Tominaga, Risa, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; Kimura, Yasuyuki, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; Tu, Trang Thi Huyen, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Basic Dental Sciences, University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nagamine, Takahiko, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Psychiatric Internal Medicine, Sunlight Brain Research Center, Yamaguchi, Japan; Toyofuku, Akira, Department of Psychosomatic Dentistry, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Burning mouth syndrome (BMS) is characterized by burning sensations in the oral region without corresponding abnormalities and is often accompanied by uncomfortable sensations. Herein, we present cases of BMS in which the remaining uncomfortable sensations improved with perospirone augmentation with clonazepam. Case 1: A 61-year-old man complained of a burning pain in his tongue, a sensation of dryness and discomfort as if his tongue was sticking to a palatal plate. With the diagnosis of BMS, psychopharmacotherapy was initiated with amitriptyline. At the dose of amitriptyline 50 mg, the pain lessened but uncomfortable sensations persisted. Further attempts to alleviate symptoms by combining aripiprazole with amitriptyline, aripiprazole with mirtazapine, or aripiprazole with clonazepam were limited; however, nearly all symptoms were relieved by a combination of perospirone 8.0 mg with clonazepam 1.5 mg. Case 2: A 51-year-old woman complained of a burning sensation along with oral dryness and crumb-like feeling on her tongue. She was diagnosed with BMS and began treatment with amitriptyline. Her burning sensation improved at the dose of 25 mg, but uncomfortable sensations persisted. Augmentation of amitriptyline with aripiprazole, aripiprazole either with valproate, mirtazapine, or clonazepam failed to produce a significant improvement. However, a regimen of perospirone 6.0 mg and clonazepam 1.5 mg relieved the crumb-like sensation and pain and culminated in a stabilized condition. The reported cases suggested that multiple approaches targeting the dopaminergic circuit in basal ganglia involving the serotoninergic and GABA systems, through the administration of perospirone with clonazepam is an effective adjunctive treatment for the remaining uncomfortable sensations in patients with BMS. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Ho, Duc Sy Minh (59136490900); Zaitsu, Takashi (57211398215); Ihira, Hikaru (36637401300); Iwasaki, Masanori (23977972300); Yoshihara, Akihiro (55552183400); Suzuki, Seitaro (57189637053); Inoue, Manami (8889234100); Yamagishi, Kazumasa (35231751500); Yasuda, Nobufumi (7202855526); Aida, Jun (57565033100)
Title: Association Between Oral Malodor and Dementia: An 11-Year Follow-Up Study in Japan
Affiliations: Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; University Medicine and Pharmacy, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Sapporo Medical University, Sapporo, Japan; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Niigata University, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Science, Niigata, Japan; National Cancer Center Japan, Tokyo, Japan; National Cancer Center Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Faculty of Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Kochi Medical School, Nankoku, Japan; Tokyo University of Science, Tokyo, Japan; Yokohama staatliche Univ, Yokohama, Japan; International University of Health and Welfare, Otawara, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ho, Duc Sy Minh, Department of Oral Health Promotion, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan, Faculty of Odonto-Stomatology, University Medicine and Pharmacy, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Zaitsu, Takashi, Department of Oral Health Promotion, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan; Ihira, Hikaru, Department of Physical Therapy, Sapporo Medical University, Sapporo, Japan; Iwasaki, Masanori, Department of Preventive Dentistry, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Yoshihara, Akihiro, Division of Oral Science for Health Promotion, Niigata University, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Science, Niigata, Japan; Suzuki, Seitaro, Division of Cohort Research, National Cancer Center Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Inoue, Manami, Division of Cohort Research, National Cancer Center Japan, Tokyo, Japan, Division of Prevention, National Cancer Center Japan, Tokyo, Japan; Yamagishi, Kazumasa, Department of Public Health Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan; Yasuda, Nobufumi, Department of Public Health, Kochi Medical School, Nankoku, Japan; Aida, Jun, Department of Oral Health Promotion, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Background: As infrequent social interaction is a potential risk of dementia, oral malodor may increase the risk of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease. Objective: This study investigated the association between malodor and dementia. Methods: We used the Japan Public Health Center-based Prospective Study data obtained at Yokote City. A total of 1,493 individuals aged 56 to 75 years underwent a dental examination and self-reported survey from May 2005 to January 2006. Follow-up for the onset of dementia was conducted using long-term care insurance data from 2006 to 2016. Hazard ratios of oral malodor on dementia were estimated by the Cox proportional hazards model. The inverse probability-weighted Cox model was used as a sensitivity analysis. Results: The study comprised 1493 participants (53.6% women) with a mean age of 65.6 (SD = 5.8) years old; at the end of the follow-up, 6.4% (n = 96) developed dementia, and the percentage was 20.7 in severe malodor group. Throughout 15274.133 person-years of follow-up, the average incidence rate for the onset of dementia per 1000 person-years was 6.29. The highest incidence rate was seen in participants with severe malodor (22.4 per 1000 person-years). After adjusting for confounders, compared to those with no malodor, there was a 3.8 (95% confidence interval: 1.5 to 9.4) times greater hazard of developing dementia in participants with severe malodor. The inverse probability weighted Cox model confirmed the same trend with an adjusted marginal hazard ratio of 4.4 (1.2 to 16.4). CONCLUSIONS: A significant association between oral malodor and the onset of dementia exists. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

H., International Islamic University Malaysia, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Ahmedi, Vjollca, University of Pristine, Pristina, Kuwait; Agostini, Maximilian, Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands, Wayne State University, Detroit, United States
Abstract: The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic saw a shift toward a more traditional division of labor–one where women took greater responsibility for household tasks and childcare than men. We tested whether this regressive shift was more acutely perceived and experienced by women in countries with greater gender equality. Cross-cultural longitudinal survey data for women and men (N = 10,238) was collected weekly during the first few months of the pandemic. Multilevel modelling analyses, based on seven waves of data collection, indicated that a regressive shift was broadly perceived but not uniformly felt. Women and men alike perceived a shift toward a more traditional division of household labor during the first few weeks of the pandemic. However, this perception only undermined women’s satisfaction with their personal relationships and subjective mental health if they lived in countries with higher levels of economic gender equality. Among women in countries with lower levels of economic gender equality, the perceived shift predicted higher relationship satisfaction and mental health. There were no such effects among men. Taken together, our results suggest that subjective perceptions of disempowerment, and the gender role norms that underpin them, should be considered when examining the gendered impact of global crisis. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Division Of Labor; Gender Equality; Gender Roles; Interpersonal Relationships; Relationship Quality; Well Being

Authors: D.K., Behera, Deepak Kumar; D.B., Rahut, Dil Bahadur; M., Padmaja, M.; A.K., Dash, Ajit Kumar
Author full names: Behera, Deepak Kumar (56959992500); Rahut, Dil Bahadur (56962787600); Padmaja, M. (57211101093); Dash, Ajit Kumar (58913023600)
Title: Socioeconomic determinants of happiness: Empirical evidence from developed and developing countries
Source title: Journal of Behavioral and Experimental Economics
Affiliations: RMIT University Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; National Institute of Technology, Kuruskshetra, India; Birla Global University, Bhubaneswar, India
Authors with affiliations: Behera, Deepak Kumar, Department of Economics and Finance, RMIT University Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Rahut, Dil Bahadur, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Padmaja, M., Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, National Institute of Technology, Kuruskshetra, India; Dash, Ajit Kumar, Department of Economics, Birla Global University, Bhubaneswar, India
Abstract: This study aims to understand the factors that contribute to people's happiness or life satisfaction in 166 countries (51 developed, 115 developing) from 2005 to 2020. The study considers the effects of various socioeconomic factors, such as per capita income, social support, freedom to make life choices, perception of corruption, air pollution exposure, and gender inequality, on the level of happiness. We used panel two-way robust fixed effects and panel quantile regression for empirical analysis. The results show that per capita income, social support, and freedom to make life choices positively impact happiness, while air pollution exposure has a negative impact. However, gender inequality does not significantly affect happiness levels. These findings highlight the relevance of the Easterlin Paradox, which suggests that income can mediate happiness by promoting emotional well-being, gender equality, and a clean environment. Therefore, policymakers should focus on creating a more holistic approach to improving the well-being and happiness of its citizens. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air Pollution Exposure; Easterlin Paradox; Freedom To Make Life Choices; Gender Inequality; Happiness Determinants; Social Support; Socioeconomic Factors

Authors with affiliations: Roskam, Isabelle, Department of Psychology, Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Aguiar, Joyce, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Akgün, Ege, Ankara Üniversitesi, Ankara, Turkey; Arena, Andrew F., UNSW Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Eryılmaz, Günce Sabah, Özyeğin Üniversitesi, Istanbul, Turkey; Aunola, Kaisa, University of Jyväskylä, Jyvaskyla, Finland; Besson, Eliane, Université Saint-Joseph de Beyrouth, Beirut, Lebanon; Beyers, Wim, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Boujut, Emilie, Laboratoire de Psychopathologie et Processus de Santé, Université de Paris, Boulogne-Billancourt, France; Brianda, Maria Elena, Université de Liège, Liege, Belgium
Abstract: Purpose: The prevalence of parental burnout, a condition that has severe consequences for both parents and children, varies dramatically across countries and is highest in Western countries characterized by high individualism. Method: In this study, we examined the mediators of the relationship between individualism measured at the country level and parental burnout measured at the individual level in 36 countries (16,059 parents). Results: The results revealed three mediating mechanisms, that is, self-discrepancies between socially prescribed and actual parental selves, high agency and self-directed socialization goals, and low parental task sharing, by which individualism leads to an increased risk of burnout among parents. Conclusion: The results confirm that the three mediators under consideration are all involved, and that mediation was higher for self-discrepancies between socially prescribed and actual parental selves, then parental task sharing, and lastly self-directed socialization goals. The results provide some important indications of how to prevent parental burnout at the societal level in Western countries. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Yoshizawa, Takeshi; A.M., M Makram, Abdelrahman M.; R., Elsheikh, Randa; S., Nakamura, Sadako; E.M., Makram, Engy Mohamed; K., Kubota, Kazumi; N.T., Huy, Nguyen Tien; K., Moji, Kazuhiko

Title: Spirituality, Quality of Life, and Health: A Japanese Cross-Sectional Study
Source title: European Journal of Investigation in Health, Psychology and Education
Affiliations: Jumonji University, Niiza, Japan; Imperial College London, London, United Kingdom; October 6 University, 6th October, Egypt; Edinburgh Medical School, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; October 6 University, 6th October, Egypt; Misr University for Science and Technology, 6th October, Egypt; The University of Tokyo Hospital, Tokyo, Japan; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshizawa, Takeshi, Graduate School of Human Life Sciences, Jumonji University, Niiza, Japan; M Makram, Abdelrahman M., School of Public Health, Imperial College London, London, United Kingdom, Department of Anesthesia and Intensive Care Medicine, October 6 University, 6th October, Egypt; Elsheikh, Randa, Edinburgh Medical School, Edinburgh, United Kingdom, Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, October 6 University, 6th October, Egypt; Nakamura, Sadako, Graduate School of Human Life Sciences, Jumonji University, Niiza, Japan; Makram, Engy Mohamed, College of Medicine, Misr University for Science and Technology, 6th October, Egypt; Kubota, Kazumi, Department of Healthcare Information Management, The University of Tokyo Hospital, Tokyo, Japan; Huy, Nguyen Tien, Institute of Research and Development, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; Moji, Kazuhiko, School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: Background: Current reports suggest a positive association between spirituality and quality of life (QoL) in elders. While most studies are qualitative studies and there has been little validation in quantitative studies using scales to measure spirituality. Hence, we aimed to study the effect of spirituality on mental health and QoL in older people residing in Kumejima Town in Japan. Methods: An interview-based survey was conducted between September 2010 and 2011 on residents of Kumejima Town aged 65 years or older. This survey-based study employed the Spirituality Health Scale for the Elderly (SP Health Scale) alongside assessments of basic attributes (e.g., age, sex); physical, mental, social health, spirituality, and QoL. We conducted a causal structure model to explore causal relationships between these factors. Results: Our study included 338 participants, including 72.5% female with an average age and standard deviation of 77.2 ± 6.4 years. Our analysis revealed a significant association between spiritual health and QoL even after accounting for the impact of physical and mental health, which challenged the conventional belief that QoL inevitably diminishes with age and declining health. These results suggest that enhancing spirituality may offer a means to prevent declines in QoL, fostering a positive outlook on life as individuals age. Conclusion: Our study suggests that improving spiritual health can enhance QoL, even in the presence of health challenges and aging. This novel perspective opens doors to redefining health as a state that coexists with illness, with spirituality serving as an integral component. A shift in our understanding of health that prioritizes spirituality, could benefit people of all ages, offering a more holistic approach to well-being that aligns with new medical technologies and evolving perceptions of health. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Health; Quality Of Life; Spirituality
References: Basic Documents, (2020); McCartney, Gerry, Defining health and health inequalities, Public Health, 172, pp. 22-30, (2019); 1st International Conference on Health Promotion Ottawa, (1986); Pharmacoecon Outcomes News, (2021); Huber, Machteld, How should we define health?, BMJ, 343, 7817, (2011); Fifty Second World Health Assembly Geneva 17 25 May 1999 Summary Records of Committees and Ministerial Round Tables Reports of Committees, (1999); de Brito Sena, Marina Aline, Defining Spirituality in Healthcare: A Systematic Review and Conceptual Framework, Frontiers in Psychology, 12, (2021); Proc Bayl Univ Med Cent, (2001); Man S Search for Meaning, (1963); Foglio, John P., Religion, faith, and family medicine, Journal of Family Practice, 27, 5, pp. 473-474, (1988)

Authors: N., Hoang-Tung, N.; H., Kato, Hironori; H.T., Linh, Hoang Thuy; H., van Cuong, Hoang; L.B., Phan, Le Binh; S., Takeda, Shinichi
Author full names: Hoang-Tung, N. (55911948300); Kato, Hironori (35323591900); Linh, Hoang Thuy (57511135900); van Cuong, Hoang (57405631100); Phan, Le Binh (57219442371); Takeda, Shinichi (57404483700)
Title: Ride-hailing service availability and private transportation mode usage in a motorcycle-based city: Evidence from Hanoi
Affiliations: Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Japan International Cooperation Agency, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hoang-Tung, N., Faculty of Construction Management, Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kato, Hironori, Department of Civil Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Linh, Hoang Thuy, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Trường Đại học Giao thông vận tải, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Cuong, Hoang, Master's Program in Environmental Engineering, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phan, Le Binh, Japan International Cooperation Agency, Tokyo, Japan; Takeda, Shinichi, Master's Program in Environmental Engineering, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Ride-hailing services (RHS) are widely expected to serve as an alternative to conventional private transportation modes. However, numerous studies on RHS's impact on private modes’ usage provide inconclusive evidence. Notably, few studies have analyzed RHS's impacts on modal changes in the context of motorcycle-based societies. This study attempts to identify the critical factors affecting RHS users’ private mode usage (private cars and motorcycles) in response to RHS appearance in Hanoi, Vietnam, a motorcycle-based society. Two empirical analyses were performed with sample data of 642 individuals collected from face-to-face interviews using paper-based questionnaire sheets in Hanoi from December 19 to 21, 2020. The first analysis employed a linear regression model to explain the changes in individuals’ private mode usage before and after RHS adoption. The second analysis estimated a logistic regression model to examine an individual's private mode choice when RHS are unavailable. Robustness tests were also performed. The results revealed that RHS users’ future vehicle ownership intentions, reasons for using RHS instead of private modes, motorcycle ownership, and public transport usage significantly reduce the impacts of RHS on private mode usage. The reasons for using RHS rather than private modes were found not strong enough to make an essential change to reduce the frequency of private modes usage. The results also showed there is a difference between the RHS's impacts on motorcycle use and car use. They suggested that policy makers should be aware of the unique factors in motorcycle-based societies such as Hanoi when formulating urban transportation strategies. Finally, the findings further supported an idea that multivariate analyses are more suitable than the simple descriptive statistics method to understand how the motivation for using RHS influences the impacts of RHS on private mode usage. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Modal Choice; Motorcycle-based Society; Private Mode; Ride-hailing Service

Abstract: Virus mitigation behavior has been and still is a powerful means to fight the COVID-19 pandemic irrespective of the availability of pharmaceutical means (e.g., vaccines). We drew on health behavior theories to predict health-protective (coping-specific) responses and hope (coping non-specific response) from health-related cognitions (vulnerability, severity, self-assessed knowledge, efficacy). In an extension of this model, we proposed orientation to internal (problem-focused coping) and external (country capability) coping resources as antecedents of health protection and hope; health-related cognitions were assumed as mediators of this link. We tested these predictions in a large multi-national multi-wave study with a cross-sectional panel at T1 (Baseline, March-April 2020; N = 57,631 in 113 countries) and a panel subsample at two later time points, T2 (November 2020; N = 3097) and T3 (April 2021; N = 2628). Multilevel models showed that health-related cognitions predicted health-protective responses and hope. Problem-focused coping was mainly linked to health-protective behaviors (T1-T3), whereas country capability was mainly linked to hope (T1-T3). These relationships were partially mediated by health-related cognitions. We conceptually replicated predictions of health behavior theories within a real health threat, further suggesting how different coping resources are associated with qualitatively distinct outcomes. Both patterns were consistent across countries and time. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Coping; Country Capability; Covid-19; Health Behavior Theories; Hope; Problem-focused Coping; Virus Mitigation Behavior

Authors: H., Kim, Hyeonmo; H., Kim, Hanju; M., Cho, Myungha; B., Vo, Bay; J.C.W., Lin, Jerry Chun Wei; H., Fujita, Hamido; U., Yun, Unil
Title: Efficient approach of high average utility pattern mining with indexed list-based structure in dynamic environments
Affiliations: Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Silesian University of Technology, Gliwice, Poland; Universiti Teknologi Malaysia Kuala Lumpur, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Instituto Andaluz Interuniversitario en Data Science and Computational Intelligence, Granada, Spain; Iwate Prefectural University, Iwate District, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Hyeonmo, Department of Computer Engineering, Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Hanju, Department of Computer Engineering, Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea; Cho, Myungha, Department of Computer Engineering, Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea; Vo, Bay, Faculty of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Lin, Jerry Chun Wei, Faculty of Automatic Control, Silesian University of Technology, Gliwice, Poland; Fujita, Hamido, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia Kuala Lumpur, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Instituto Andaluz Interuniversitario en Data Science and Computational Intelligence, Granada, Spain, Regional Research Center, Iwate Prefectural University, Iwate District, Japan; Yun, Unil, Department of Computer Engineering, Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Various studies on high utility pattern mining have been conducted to satisfy the emerging need to consider the characteristics of real-world databases, such as the importance and quantity of items. In the traditional utility-based framework, the mining result is influenced by the number of items in a pattern, or in some cases, single utilities of items. In order to overcome this drawback, high average utility pattern mining has been proposed. It provides more interesting results since it takes into account the average utility of patterns by considering their lengths. Methods based on this concept have emerged in recent years, including ones that target incremental environments. However, existing algorithms create an enormous number of candidate patterns or require complex operations during the mining process. To address this degradation, we propose a new and more efficient approach for mining high average utility patterns in dynamic environments. The proposed algorithm utilizes a data structure more efficient than previous ones, which takes the form of an indexed list. It also incorporates efficient realigning and mining techniques for handling incremental data and accurately mining results. Experimental results show the superiority of the proposed approach in terms of runtime, memory usage, scalability, and accuracy. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Data Mining; Dynamic Data Mining; High Average Utility Patterns; Indexed List Based Structure; Pattern Pruning; Data Handling; Average Utilities; Candidate Patterns; Dynamic Data Mining; Dynamic Environments; High Average Utility Pattern; Indexed List Based Structure; Pattern Mining; Pattern Pruning; Real-world Database; Utility-based Framework; Data Mining

Abstract: Coronavirus Anxiety Scale (CAS)is a widely used measure that captures somatic symptoms of coronavirus- related anxiety. In a large-scale collaboration spanning 60 countries (Ntotal = 21,513), we examined the CAS’s measurement invariance and assessed the convergent validity of CAS scores in relation to the fear of COVID-19(FCV-19S) and the satisfaction with life (SWLS-3) scales. We utilized both conventional exact invariance tests and alignmentprocedures,with results revealing that the single-factor model fit the data well in almost all countries. Partial scalar invariance was supported in a subset of 56 countries. To ensure the robustness of results, given the unbalanced samples, we employed resampling techniques both with and without replacement and found the results were more stable in larger samples. The alignment procedure demonstrated a high degree of measurement invariance with 9% of the parameters exhibiting non-invariance. Wealso conducted simulations of alignment using the parameters estimated in the current model. Findings demonstrated reliability of the means but indicated challenges in estimating the latent variances. Strong positive correlations between CAS and FCV-19S estimated with all three different approaches were found in most countries. Correlations of CAS and SWLS-3were weakandnegativebutsignificantly differed from zero in several countries. Overall, the study provided support for the measurement invariance of the CAS and offered evidence of its convergent validity while also highlighting issues with variance estimation. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.V., Ha, Nguyen Viet; T., Nguyen Tuan Kiet, Tran; T.T., Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi; M.M.T., Tsuru, Masato M.T.
Author full names: Ha, Nguyen Viet (24343793500); Nguyen Tuan Kiet, Tran (59563831500); Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi (57211186664); Tsuru, Masato M.T. (7005093872)
Title: Real-Time In-Band Packet Loss Recovery for Reliable Multicast Protocols Utilizing Programmable Data Planes
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ha, Nguyen Viet, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen Tuan Kiet, Tran, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tsuru, Masato M.T., Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Abstract: Unicast communication is inefficient for modern networks that need to deliver the same data to multiple recipients, such as in cloud services, Internet of Things (IoT) networks, and smart city systems. Unicast causes congestion, wasted bandwidth, and poor scalability. Reliable multicast protocols address these challenges by enabling simultaneous data transmission to multiple destinations, reducing both network traffic and resource consumption. However, loss recovery remains a critical issue, as delays can significantly impact overall performance. We propose a new scheme that leverages programmable data plane-enabled switches, such as P4-enabled switches, to detect and retransmit packet losses at each switch. In this scheme, the receiving node (switch) detects lost packets in real-time and requests retransmissions from the neighboring nodes. The scheme operates transparently between source and destination hosts, making it compatible with existing networks and applicable to any network application or protocol. Simulations using ns-3 demonstrate that our scheme significantly improves the completion time of file transfers based on reliable multicast protocols in high link loss scenarios. For example, it reduces completion time by up to 36% when delivering a 1 GB file from one source to 40 sinks with a link loss rate of 0.01. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.H., Nguyen, Duong H.; P., Nguyen, Phile; T., Nguyen, Truongthao; H.H., Pham, Huy Hieu; D.A., Tran, Duc A.
Author full names: Nguyen, Duong H. (59297225500); Nguyen, Phile (56244958800); Nguyen, Truongthao (57192716466); Pham, Huy Hieu (57201117744); Tran, Duc A. (7102150811)
Title: FedBlock: A Blockchain Approach to Federated Learning against Backdoor Attacks
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; VinUniversity, Hanoi, Viet Nam; University of Massachusetts Boston, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duong H., Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Phile, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Truongthao, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Pham, Huy Hieu, VinUniversity, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Duc A., University of Massachusetts Boston, Boston, United States
Abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is a machine learning method for training with private data locally stored in distributed machines without gathering them into one place for central learning. Despite its promises, FL is prone to critical security risks. First, because FL depends on a central server to aggregate local training models, this is a single point of failure. The server might function maliciously. Second, due to its distributed nature, FL might encounter backdoor attacks by participating clients. They can poison the local model before submitting to the server. Either type of attack, on the server or the client side, would severely degrade learning accuracy. We propose FedBlock, a novel blockchain-based FL framework that addresses both of these security risks. FedBlock is uniquely desirable in that it involves only smart contract programming, thus deployable atop any blockchain network. Our framework is substantiated with a comprehensive evaluation study using real-world datasets. Its robustness against backdoor attacks is competitive with the literature of FL backdoor defense. The latter, however, does not address the server risk as we do. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.D., Tran, Van Duy; T., Xuan Hieu Le, Tran; T.D., Tran, Thi Diem; H., Luan Pham, Hoai; V.T., Duong Le, Vu Trung; T., Hai Vu, Tuan; V.T., Nguyen, Van Tinh; Y., Nakashima, Yasuhiko
Author full names: Tran, Van Duy (58100217800); Xuan Hieu Le, Tran (59540944000); Tran, Thi Diem (57219502897); Luan Pham, Hoai (58876679100); Duong Le, Vu Trung (57218563336); Hai Vu, Tuan (59367377400); Nguyen, Van Tinh (57192092247); Nakashima, Yasuhiko (7201863420)
Title: Exploring the Limitations of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks in Classification: Insights to Software Training and Hardware Implementation
Affiliations: Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Van Duy, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Xuan Hieu Le, Tran, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Thi Diem, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Luan Pham, Hoai, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Duong Le, Vu Trung, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Hai Vu, Tuan, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Nguyen, Van Tinh, Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nakashima, Yasuhiko, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan
Abstract: Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs), a novel type of neural network, have recently gained popularity and attention due to the ability to substitute multi-layer perceptions (MLPs) in artificial intelligence (AI) with higher accuracy and interoperability. However, KAN assessment is still limited and cannot provide an in-depth analysis of a specific domain. Furthermore, no study has been conducted on the implementation of KANs in hardware design, which would directly demonstrate whether KANs are truly superior to MLPs in practical applications. As a result, in this paper, we focus on verifying KANs for classification issues, which are a common but significant topic in AI using four different types of datasets. Furthermore, the corresponding hardware implementation is considered using the Vitis high-level synthesis (HLS) tool. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first article to implement hardware for KAN. The results indicate that KANs cannot achieve more accuracy than MLPs in high complex datasets while utilizing substantially higher hardware resources. Therefore, MLP remains an effective approach for achieving accuracy and efficiency in software and hardware implementation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.H., Tran, Thai Ha; D.T., Dam, Duc Thuan; B., Kieu-Do-Nguyen, Binh; V.P., Hoang, Van Phuc; T.T., Hoang, Trong Thuc; C.K., Pham, Cong Kha
Author full names: Tran, Thai Ha (57216154297); Dam, Duc Thuan (58643182400); Kieu-Do-Nguyen, Binh (57200626731); Hoang, Van Phuc (37034022300); Hoang, Trong Thuc (56024762000); Pham, Cong Kha (56186480400)
Title: Hardware Implementation of a Hybrid Dynamic Gold Code-Based Countermeasure Against Side-Channel Attacks
Affiliations: The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Thai Ha, Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Dam, Duc Thuan, Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Kieu-Do-Nguyen, Binh, Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Hoang, Van Phuc, Institute of System Integration, Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoang, Trong Thuc, Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Pham, Cong Kha, Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan
Abstract: Side-channel attacks have emerged as the predominant approach for exploiting the weaknesses of cryptographic equipment. Therefore, it is becoming increasingly necessary to prioritize countermeasures that can improve the security level of these implementations. A Mixed-Mode Clock Manager (MMCM) primitive has been utilized in several time-based hiding countermeasures against side-channel attacks. However, they cannot be applied to ASIC implementations because the MMCM is a Xilinx primitive. Consequently, this paper proposes a hybrid dynamic Gold code-based solution to generate multiple different frequencies. The countermeasure combines a pair of preferred polynomials with one ring oscillator, so it is suitable for both FPGA and ASIC designs. The hardware overhead of our suggested architecture is 1.007× and 1.009× in terms of slice LUTs and registers, respectively. The total area cost of the circuit on the CMOS 0.18 um process is 398,835 square micrometers, representing a 1.004x increase compared to the unprotected case. Moreover, the approach is resistant to both standard and sliding window-based Correlation Power Analysis attacks, even when employing UP to one million power traces. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Kosuke, Tanizaki; F., Keisuke, Furumoto; M., Kohei, Masumi; H., Trong-Minh, Hoang; S., Yoshiaki, Shiraishi; T., Takeshi, Takahashi
Author full names: Kosuke, Tanizaki (59517737300); Keisuke, Furumoto (59517633900); Kohei, Masumi (59517536700); Trong-Minh, Hoang (59517536800); Yoshiaki, Shiraishi (59517737400); Takeshi, Takahashi (59517536900)
Title: Investigating Agricultural IoT Devices and Services from Cybersecurity Perspectives
Affiliations: Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kosuke, Tanizaki, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Keisuke, Furumoto, National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Kohei, Masumi, National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Trong-Minh, Hoang, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yoshiaki, Shiraishi, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Takeshi, Takahashi, National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan
Abstract: The rise of smart farm has led to the increasing use of devices with communication capabilities in the agricultural field. Although papers and security reports have warned about the necessity of security measures for IoT devices used in the industrial field, there is little existing research that investigates the actual state of these measures. In this paper, we first developed a list of 175 agricultural IoT devices, followed by a taxonomy based on that list. Next, using Shodan's observation network, we conducted a large-scale survey of agricultural IoT devices (including systems and services that include agricultural IoT devices within themselves) that are publicly available on the Internet to investigate the actual security of agricultural IoT devices. In addition, this study also examines security risks related to agricultural IoT devices that may emerge in the future and current standards that can be used as countermeasures. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Promoting Open Data Utilization in Infrastructure Management Through an Integrated System of Data Processing, Cloud Storage, and Visualization
Affiliations: Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Tottori University, Tottori, Japan; Mientrung University of Civil Engineering, Tuy Hoa, Viet Nam

Abstract: During the rapid economic growth of Japan in the 1960s, the country's infrastructure development progressed swiftly. Since 2014, the Japanese government has mandated regular inspections of major urban infrastructure. This policy has resulted in the annual accumulation of substantial amounts of infrastructure inspection data. Two years prior to implementing this policy, the Japanese government also launched an open data initiative to encourage industry developers to utilize open data. However, this study observes that inconsistencies in data formatting and standards across different regions pose significant challenges to the utilization of this data. To address the obstacles hindering the use of open data, this study proposes an integrated system(Service Link Platform) for effectively managing and utilizing periodic transportation infrastructure inspection data which encompasses data collection, data format processing, cloud storage and transmission, and data utilization. This article will layout the manner in which the system employs a method for distributing data in JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) format to publicly manage bridge inspection data and ensure compatibility of data formats. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Hoshino, Yukinobu; N., Rathnayake, Namal; T.L., Dang, Tuan Linh; U.S., Rathnayake, Upaka Sanjeewa
Author full names: Hoshino, Yukinobu (9334496600); Rathnayake, Namal (57223281113); Dang, Tuan Linh (57188972066); Rathnayake, Upaka Sanjeewa (57211021071)
Title: Empirical Research on 3D Analysis and Flow Prediction of Upstream Rivers Using Drones
Affiliations: Kochi University of Technology, Kami, Japan; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Atlantic Technology University (ATU), Sligo, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Hoshino, Yukinobu, School of Systems Engineering, Kochi University of Technology, Kami, Japan; Rathnayake, Namal, River and Environmental Engineering Laboratory, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Dang, Tuan Linh, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Rathnayake, Upaka Sanjeewa, Faculty of Engineering and Design, Atlantic Technology University (ATU), Sligo, Ireland
Abstract: This study aims to develop an AI prediction system for watersheds, utilizing data from Sri Lanka and Vietnam in collaboration with overseas researchers. Initially, a foundational AI prediction system will be constructed, and basic data will be gathered based on river data from Japan. Subsequently, topographic data of the watershed area, managed by the joint research partner institution, will be incorporated into the AI prediction system through drone-based aerial measurement and analysis. Moreover, visits to the joint research institution will be conducted to gather information on water damage and electricity supply. This information will then be integrated into the AI prediction system. Utilizing the collected data and additional observation data, efforts will be made to enhance the accuracy of the AI prediction algorithm, identify potential issues, and overcome them. The ultimate goal is to establish new AI pre-diction technology by comparing the results of this study with both domestic and international research outcomes. This paper will present data from a drone scan of the upstream watershed and discuss the future use of AI based on the results of three-dimensional analysis and image processing. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B.T., Ngo, Binh Tan; N.H.H., Thai, Nghi Hoang Huu; H.L., Pham, Hoai Luan; T.D., Tran, Thi Diem
Author full names: Ngo, Binh Tan (59460392100); Thai, Nghi Hoang Huu (59459424600); Pham, Hoai Luan (57207990013); Tran, Thi Diem (57219502897)
Title: A High-Performance FPGA Based on Convolutional Neural Network for QRS Complex Detection
Affiliations: VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ngo, Binh Tan, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thai, Nghi Hoang Huu, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Pham, Hoai Luan, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan; Tran, Thi Diem, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Mortality rates from cardiovascular issues have risen, especially among younger people. ECG signals, particularly the QRS complex, are vital for monitoring heart activity and detecting arrhythmias. A high-performance, low-power system is essential for diagnosing heart diseases. We present a hardware accelerator using a deep neural network to detect QRS complexes, enhancing energy efficiency. Our algorithm adjusts the number of parallel multipliers, reducing latency without extra hardware. We also developed a new method for the softmax layer that maintains accuracy with less hardware. Our design achieves a sensitivity (Se) of 0.99797 and a positive predictive value (+P) of 0.99936, comparable to the state-of-the-art on the MIT-BIH database. It operates at a maximum frequency of 320 MHz, consuming only 0.11 W, and reduces latency by 50% compared to conventional pipelines. Additionally, it outperforms CPU and GPU solutions in speed. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Convolutional Neural Network; Fpga; Latency; Qrs Complex Detection; Sopc

Title: Predicting Self-Esteem Using Humor Styles: A Cross-Cultural Study
Affiliations: Western University, London, Canada; The Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria; Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski University in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland; Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski University in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland; NUCB Business School, Nagoya, Japan; Western University, London, Canada; Singidunum University, Belgrade, Serbia; Uniwersytet Jagielloński, Krakow, Poland; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Daugavpils University, Daugavpils, Latvia; University of Sargodha, Sargodha, Pakistan; Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Universidad de Jaén, Jaen, Spain; Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety – Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Universidad de Granada, Granada, Spain; Universidad Católica del Norte, Antofagasta, Chile; Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Kuban State University, Krasnodar, Russian Federation; University College of Teacher Education Styria, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Schermer, Julie Aitken, Management and Organizational Studies, Western University, London, Canada; Papazova, Eva Boyanova, Department of Psychology, The Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria; Kwiatkowska, Maria Magdalena, Faculty of Christian Philosophy, Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski University in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland; Rogoza, Radosław, Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski University in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland; Park, Joonha, NUCB Business School, Nagoya, Japan; Kowalski, Christopher Marcin, Department of Psychology, Western University, London, Canada; Branković, Marija, Faculty of Media and Communications, Singidunum University, Belgrade, Serbia; Doroszuk, Marta, Faculty of Philosophy, Uniwersytet Jagielloński, Krakow, Poland; Khanh Ha, Truong Thi, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Iliško, Dzintra, Institute of Humanities and Social Sciences, Daugavpils University, Daugavpils, Latvia
Abstract: The present study examines the question of whether certain humor styles predict self-esteem. Men and women in 15 countries (NTOTAL = 4701) completed self-report measures assessing self-esteem and the four humor styles of affiliative, aggressive, self-defeating, and self-enhancing. Each of the country samples had self-esteem averages at or above the midpoint of the scale, but did vary. The samples from Colombia and Serbia had the highest self-esteem values and Russia had the lowest. For all of the country samples, with the exception of Russia, the multiple regression results demonstrated that a greater level of the self-enhancing humor style positively predicted higher self-esteem scores. As the self-enhancing humor style involves improving one’s mood with humor, the results suggest that for the majority of the participants, self-enhancing humor styles also help to increase self-esteem. The results are discussed both within countries and across the samples. In particular, the unique finding that not a self-enhancing humor style but an aggressive humor style predicts self-esteem in the Russian sample is discussed. The chapter ends with a discussion of how humor styles correlate with mental health indicators and how the understanding of humor style profiles are related to well-being across countries adds to the global understanding of individual differences. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Proposing to Use Backstepping Controller for Sitting/Lying Type Lower Limb Rehabilitation Robot
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; National Institute of Patent and Technology Exploitation (NIPTECH), Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Thanh Trung, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Hoang Minh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Manh Tien, Graduate School, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Luu, Tien Duc, National Institute of Patent and Technology Exploitation (NIPTECH), Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The WHO predicts that by 2050 the total number of elderly people will double, accompanied by an increase in related diseases. As life becomes more modern and convenient, the average age lengthens and the number of elderly people increases. The post-injury rehabilitation process has been developed for many years, but the human resources for that process are too small, leading to a situation where many patients do not receive proper treatment. From there, we see an essential need for lower limb rehabilitation. This study focuses on studying the controller for the sitting/lying rehabilitation robot being developed. The research process starts from collecting documents on robot control models for lower limb rehabilitation and the most suitable input trajectories. The research processed starts from collecting documents on robot control models for lower limb rehabilitation and the most suitable input trajectories. After that, the research would go into applying the Backstepping control method to the Robot, through fine-tuning the coefficients and experimenting with different step cycles. These experimental results are compared with the case of using PID controller and Backstepping controller, showing significantly better quality. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Retail Store Customer Behavior Analysis System: Design and Implementation
Source title: IFIP Advances in Information and Communication Technology
Affiliations: Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dinh, Tuan Nguyen, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hihara, Keisuke, Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Hoang, Tung Cao, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Utada, Yumeka, Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Torii, Akihiko, Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Izumi, Naoki, Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Thuy, Nguyen Thanh, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Du Tien, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Long Quoc, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Understanding customer behavior in retail stores plays a crucial role in improving customer satisfaction by adding personalized value to services. Behavior analysis reveals both general and detailed patterns in the interaction of customers with a store’s items and other people, providing store managers with insight into customer preferences. Several solutions aim to utilize this data by recognizing specific behaviors through statistical visualization. However, current approaches are limited to the analysis of small customer behavior sets, utilizing conventional methods to detect behaviors. They do not use deep learning techniques such as deep neural networks, which are powerful methods in the field of computer vision. Furthermore, these methods provide limited figures when visualizing the behavioral data acquired by the system. In this study, we propose a framework that includes three primary parts: mathematical modeling of customer behaviors, behavior analysis using an efficient deep learning-based system, and individual and group behavior visualization. Each module and the entire system were validated using data from actual situations in a retail store. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.V., Ha, Nguyen Viet; T.N., Tuan Kiet, Tran Nguyen; B.N., Thanh Binh, Bui Ngoc; N.M., Tri, Nguyen Minh; T.T., Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi; M.M.T., Tsuru, Masato M.T.
Author full names: Ha, Nguyen Viet (24343793500); Tuan Kiet, Tran Nguyen (59007134000); Thanh Binh, Bui Ngoc (59007085200); Tri, Nguyen Minh (58402907800); Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi (57211186664); Tsuru, Masato M.T. (7005093872)
Title: Real-Time In-Band Network Link Loss Detection With Programmable Data Plane
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ha, Nguyen Viet, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tuan Kiet, Tran Nguyen, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thanh Binh, Bui Ngoc, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tri, Nguyen Minh, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tsuru, Masato M.T., Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Abstract: Quality commitment is essential in providing network services and applications to clients. The packet loss in the network, due to link corruption and congestion, causes the performance degradation of many network services, affecting the application experience. Packet loss often happens in both lossy networks like wireless networks and reliable local networks like data center networks. The previous papers proposed methods to estimate the link loss (packet loss on link) and feedback to the controller via the OpenFlow. However, the feedback process passively depends on the scheduled OpenFlow Flow-Stat packet sent from the controller, resulting in late detection and response to the loss events. Besides, the accumulated loss in a path with multiple nodes causes a less accurate estimation at the node far from the measurement host due to insufficient probe packets. Therefore, this paper proposes a new scheme based on programmable data plane-enabled switches, such as the P4-enabled switch, to actively calculate the link loss and send the feedback to the controller. It also ensures the total probe packet at all links always equals the one that departs from the measurement host by supplementing the probe packet to compensate for the loss in the previous link. The simulation on ns-3 shows the efficiency of the proposed scheme in achieving a good accuracy estimation and a short response time to the network state change. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.X.T., Pham, Thoa Xuan Thi; K., Yokozawa, Kodo; N.N., Anh, Nguyen Ngoc
Author full names: Pham, Thoa Xuan Thi (57221293729); Yokozawa, Kodo (57217983827); Anh, Nguyen Ngoc (57216193031)
Title: The influences of boundary spanning capabilities and long–term orientation on opportunism in inter–firm relationships
Affiliations: FPT University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Thoa Xuan Thi, Faculty of Business, FPT University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yokozawa, Kodo, Department of Business Administration, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Anh, Nguyen Ngoc, Department of Social Sciences, Economic and Management, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Opportunism is a common issue in inter–firm relationships, which increases transaction costs, impairs firm performance and supply chain efficiency, and deteriorates relationship quality. Previous studies have intensively investigated factors influencing opportunism but overfocusing on the organisational level. Recently, supply chain researchers have called for identifying factors influencing opportunism at the individual level to gain a more comprehensive understanding of opportunism. Based on transaction cost theory, resource dependence theory, and boundary spanning theory, this study seeks to advance the emerging research stream on opportunism at the individual level by investigating how buyer agents’ boundary spanning capabilities and firms’ long–term relationship orientation can help manage supplier agents’ opportunism. Using a cross–sectional data set of 406 buyer agents from manufacturing companies collected from February to April 2021 in Japan, we tested a set of hypotheses through regression and conditional process analyses. Our findings suggest that buyer agents’ strategic communication and firms’ long–term relationship orientation are critical factors that reduce supplier agents’ opportunism. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Boundary Spanning Capability; Inter–firm Relationship; Japan; Long–term Orientation; Opportunism

Authors: X.M.T., Tran, Xuan Minh Tri; K., Nakamura, Keiko; S., Al-Sobaihi, Saber; K., Seino, Kaoruko
Author full names: Tran, Xuan Minh Tri (58739879500); Nakamura, Keiko (7406773103); Al-Sobaihi, Saber (56879065000); Seino, Kaoruko (8864914700)
Title: Parental engagement in caregiving activities and its association with socioeconomic and child-rearing environment at home in Vietnam
Affiliations: Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; University Medicine and Pharmacy, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Xuan Minh Tri, Department of Global Health Entrepreneurship, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Faculty of Public Health, University Medicine and Pharmacy, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nakamura, Keiko, Department of Global Health Entrepreneurship, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Al-Sobaihi, Saber, Department of Global Health Entrepreneurship, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Seino, Kaoruko, Department of Global Health Entrepreneurship, Institute of Science Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Quality caregiving practices facilitate early childhood development. This study examined the levels of parents’ engagement in caregiving activities with children aged 36–59 months and the socioeconomic and child-rearing environmental factors. A total of 1035 children and their caregivers were analysed using the Vietnam Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2014. Multivariate logistic regression was performed separately for each following outcome caregiving activity: reading books, telling stories, singing songs, naming/counting, taking the child outside, and playing with child. Results showed that fathers’ engagement levels were substantially lower than the mothers’ in all caregiving activities. Reading books and telling stories was among the least frequent activities engaged in by both parents. Results from the logistic regression model showed that parental high education level, richest household wealth, and having adequate learning resources at home were positively associated with parents’ engagement in caregiving activities. These findings provide important evidence for promoting positive parental caregiving. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Caregiving Practices; Early Childhood Development; Home Environment; Parental Engagement
Funding Texts: We express our sincere gratitude to Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey for giving us permission and access to the Vietnam MICS 2014 dataset.

P., Institute of Psychology, Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski University in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland; Nowak, Bartłomiej, Institute of Psychology, Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski University in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland; Jonason, Peter Karl, Institute of Psychology, Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski University in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland, Università degli Studi di Padova, Padua, Italy; Sedikides, Constantine, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom; Adamovic, Mladen, King's College London, London, United Kingdom; Atitsogbe, Kokou Amenyona, Université de Lausanne (UNIL), Lausanne, Switzerland; Ahmed, Oli, University of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh; Azam, Uzma, Department of Psychology, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, India
Abstract: Unfounded—conspiracy and health—beliefs about COVID-19 have accompanied the pandemic worldwide. Here, we examined cross-nationally the structure and correlates of these beliefs with an 8-item scale, using a multigroup confirmatory factor analysis. We obtained a two-factor model of unfounded (conspiracy and health) beliefs with good internal structure (average CFI = 0.98, RMSEA = 0.05, SRMR = 0.04), but a high correlation between the two factors (average latent factor correlation = 0.57). This model was replicable across 50 countries (total N = 13,579), as evidenced by metric invariance between countries (CFI = 0.96, RMSEA = 0.06, SRMS = 0.07) as well as scalar invariance across genders (CFI = 0.98, RMSEA = 0.04, SRMS = 0.03) and educational levels (CFI = 0.98, RMSEA = 0.04, SRMS = 0.03). Also, lower levels of education, more fear of COVID-19, and more cynicism were weakly associated with stronger conspiracy and health beliefs. The study contributes to knowledge about the structure of unfounded beliefs, and reveals the potential relevance of affective (i.e., fear of COVID-19) and cognitive (i.e., cynicism) factors along with demographics, in endorsing such beliefs. In summary, we obtained cross-cultural evidence for the distinctiveness of unfounded conspiracy and health beliefs about COVID-19 in terms of their structure and correlates. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Conspiracy Beliefs; Covid-19; Cross-cultural; Health Beliefs; Unfounded Beliefs

Authors: M., Tseng, Minglang; T.P.T., Tran, Thi Phuong Thuy; M., Fujii, Minoru; M.K., Lim, Ming K.; Y.T., Negash, Yeneneh Tamirat
Author full names: Tseng, Minglang (44261803600); Tran, Thi Phuong Thuy (57218381942); Fujii, Minoru (55738468000); Lim, Ming K. (7201473042); Negash, Yeneneh Tamirat (57212265634)
Title: Modelling hierarchical circular supply chain management enablers in the seafood processing industry in Vietnam under uncertainties
Source title: International Journal of Logistics Research and Applications
Affiliations: Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan; China Medical University Hospital, Taichung, Taiwan; Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia; Asia University College of Management, Taichung, Taiwan; Foreign Trade University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Tseng, Minglang, Institute of Innovation and Circular Economy, Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan, Department of Medical Research, China Medical University Hospital, Taichung, Taiwan, Faculty of Economics and Management, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia; Tran, Thi Phuong Thuy, Asia University College of Management, Taichung, Taiwan, Foreign Trade University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujii, Minoru, Center for Social and Environmental Systems Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Lim, Ming K., Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Negash, Yeneneh Tamirat, Institute of Innovation and Circular Economy, Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan, Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan
Abstract: This study establishes a valid set of circular supply chain management enablers in Vietnam under uncertainties. Circular supply chain management optimises resource utilisation and minimises waste in achieving competitive advantage; however, prior studies failed to build enablers for industrial improvement under qualitative information. This study adopts the fuzzy Delphi method to arrive at a valid group of attributes. Fuzzy set theory deals with the uncertainties from qualitative data, and fuzzy interpretive structural modelling builds the hierarchical structure under uncertainties. The best-worst method confirms the consistencies. This study stipulates a four-level hierarchical structure in the seafood processing industry. The results show that organisational capability and agility, technological advancement and economic benefit are dominant aspects. Commitment of leadership and managerial support, suppliers’ collaboration, firm culture, readiness for organisational change and sustainability concept integration are top criteria for industrial improvement. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Best-worst Method; Circular Supply Chain Management Enablers; Dynamic Capability View; Fuzzy Set Theory; Interpretive Structural Modelling; Triple Bottom Line

Author full names: Nguyen, Nhu Hoang (59256374300); Dang, Tan Phat (57219503026); Tran, Tuan Kiet (57215727984); Bui, Thanh Dat (59255594500); Hoang, Trong Thuc (56024762000); Huynh, Huu Thuan (55948143700)
Title: A Configurable 2D-Integer DCT Hardware Accelerator Compatible with H.266 Standard based on RISC-V Architecture
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Nhu Hoang, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Dang, Tan Phat, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Tuan Kiet, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bui, Thanh Dat, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hoang, Trong Thuc, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Huynh, Huu Thuan, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: This paper presents a system architecture for video compression, including a configurable 2D Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) hardware accelerator, a CPU, and Direct Memory Access (DMA), implemented on a System on Programmable Chip (SoPC) using the DE10 Pro FPGA. The proposed DCT accelerator utilizes matrix decomposition and replaces traditional multiplications with additions and bit-shifting, enabling an efficient hardware implementation. It supports both square and non-square block sizes, providing flexibility and compatibility with the H.266/VVC standard. The system integrates a NIOS-V CPU based on RISC-V architecture, memory, and DMA to ensure efficient data transfer from video compression pipeline stages like Motion Estimation and Intra/Inter Prediction. Compared to existing solutions, this design overcomes limitations in throughput and block size flexibility, achieving 11,482 Mpixels/s for 64×64 blocks on the DE10 Pro board, supporting 16K video at 60fps. Experimental results also show a throughput of 1,918 Mpixels/s for 32×32 blocks on Virtex 7, supporting 8K video at 50fps, outperforming similar designs in throughput and scalability. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Overcoming the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in great loss of life worldwide and shook the global economy, required individuals’ willingness and ability to behave prosocially. To contribute to the understanding of predictors of prosociality, we used multilevel models to test three previously established pathways to prosocial behavior, which we call the “broaden and build”, compensation, and incapacity pathways. We also tested whether these three paths are mediated by general wellbeing, and moderated by collective disempowerment, i.e., individuals’ belief that external societal forces have made it harder for people like them to function effectively. Participants from 39 countries (N= 59987) were surveyed on their willingness to engage in prosocial behaviors in the context of the pandemic. The “broaden and build” pathway was supported: positive affect was associated with willingness to engage in prosocial behavior via higher well-being. Two (in)capacity paths were also supported: financial strain and negative affect were both negatively associated with prosociality via lower well-being. A compensation pathway was also observed: Controlling for lower well-being, negative affect was associated with greater prosociality. Finally, differences in disempowerment moderated the affective pathways: higher disempowerment strengthened the positive association of positive affect with prosociality via well-being, and buffered the negative affect incapacity path. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
